children.name: to put sth in a sloping position
lean
children.definition: to put something in a sloping position where it is supported, or to be in that position :dựa

children.name: lean (sth) against/on sth
examples: A huge mirror was leaning against the wall.
He leant his bicycle against the fence.
She leaned the ladder against the house and climbed up to the window.
Soldiers leaned their M-16 rifles up against their tables as they ate.

children.name: rest
children.definition: to support an object or part of your body by putting it on or against something, or to be supported in this way →lean

children.name: rest (sth) against/on sth
examples: She slid down in her chair and rested her head on the back of the seat.
Resting his spade against the wall, he went to help Michael light the fire.
Their bikes were resting against the wall.

children.name: stand
children.definition: to lean something in an almost upright position against something such as a wall:dựng

children.name: stand sth against/in etc
examples: Maggie stood her bicycle against the wall of the shed.
Just stand it in the corner, so it doesn’t fall.
Stand the paintings against the wall while we decide where to hang them.

children.name: prop
children.definition: to lean sth against a wall or other surface, especially quickly and for a short time:dựng
examples: Can wepropthe windowopenwith something?

children.name: prop sth against sth
examples: He propped his bicycle against the fence and ran inside.
He propped his bike against a tree.

children.name: stand/lie propped against sth
examples: An old guitar lay propped against a wall.

children.name: to put several things on top of each other
pile
children.definition: to put a lot of things on top of each other, especially in an untidy way:chất đống

children.name: pile sth on/onto/there etc
examples: ▪ Gifts were piled under the Christmas tree.
▪ Has anyone else noticed that towels dry faster when you don’t pile them in the middle of the floor?

children.name: pile sth upput a lot of things on top of each other in a tall pilechất đống cái gì đó
examples: ▪ He piled his dirty laundry up just outside my door.

children.name: be piling upusethis to say a pile is growing quickly :đang chồng chất
examples: ▪ We called the police when we noticed her newspapers and mail were piling up.

children.name: stack
children.definition: /stæk/  to put things neatly on top of each other:chất thành đống
examples: ▪ I’ll start stacking the chairs.

children.name: stack something against/in/on sth
examples: ▪ Boxes were stacked in the corner.

children.name: stack sth upput a lot of things on top of each other in a tall pile:chất cái gì đó thành đống
examples: ▪ My kids leave dirty plates stacked up in the sink until I get home.

children.name: heap
children.definition: to put a lot of things on top of each other in an untidy way:chất đống
examples: heap something on/onto
▪ Cheap clothes and shoes were heaped on tables.
heap sth with sth
▪ a plate heaped with salad
heap sth in/into a pile
▪ Eileen collected the leaves, heaping them into piles for burning.
lie heaped: nằm chồng chất
▪ Her clothes lay heaped together in a corner of the room.

children.name: to put sth swh quickly or carelessly
stick
children.definition: /stɪk/  spoken to put sth somewhere, especially quickly or carelessly:dán

children.name: stick sth on/in/over sth
examples: ▪ I stuck the pictures in a drawer and forgot all about them.

children.name: ▪ ‘What should I do with these?’ ‘Oh, just stick them anywhere.’
shove
children.definition: informal to push sth quickly or carelessly into a space or container:nhét

children.name: shove sth in/into/under etc
examples: Shove anything you don’t want in that sack.
I’ve ironed those shirts so don’t just shove them in a drawer.

children.name: dump
children.definition: to carelessly drop sth somewhere in an untidy way, especially sth heavy:ném, vứt

children.name: dump sth on/there etc
examples: People dump rubbish in the lanes, and the council is slow to clean it up.
Who dumped all these books on my desk?
They dump tons of salt on icy road surfaces to make driving safer.
Don’t just dump all your bags in the kitchen.
People shouldn’t dump rubbish at the side of the street.

children.name: dump sth in/into there etc
examples: He found a can of beef stew and dumped it in a saucepan to heat.

children.name: dump sth down
examples: I dumped my heavy suitcase down on the doorstep.
Merrill dumped her suitcase down in the hall.

children.name: slam down
children.definition: /ˌslæm ˈdaʊn/  to put sth down somewhere quickly and violently because you are angry:ném phịch
examples: She slammed the cup down, and coffee splashed all over him.
‘To hell with you,’ he shouted, and slammed down the phone.

children.name: thrust
children.definition: /θrʌst/ literaryto put sth forcefully and suddenly into a place:đẩy, tống, thọc

children.name: thrust sth in/on/under etc
examples: ▪ Clark thrust a paper sack across the counter and demanded money.
▪ She thrust the bag into my hands. ‘Hide it,’ she hissed.
▪ He nervously thrust his hands into his pockets.
‘Hide it,’ he said, thrusting the watch into her hand.

children.name: pop
children.definition: informal to put sth somewhere quickly for a short time: thả, ném

children.name: pop sth in/into/under etc
examples: She took out a piece of chewing gum and popped it in her mouth.
Pop it in the microwave for a minute.

children.name: bung
children.definition: /bʌŋ/  British informal to put something somewhere quickly and without thinking carefully:ném

children.name: bung sth in/into/on etc
examples: ▪ Could you bung those clothes into the washing machine for me?
▪ Just sign the card, bung it in an envelope and send it off.

children.name: plonk
children.definition: especially UK /plunkUS  to put sth down somewhere noisily and carelessly:ném, vứt

children.name: plonk sth on/in/there etc
examples: ▪ She brought a bottle of beer and a glass and plonked them on the table in front of me.
▪ Gamblers plunked nickels and quarters into the slot machines.

children.name: plonk sth down
examples: ▪ Are those things for me? Just plonk them down anywhere.
▪ Gary plunked a dollar down on the counter to pay for his Coke.

children.name: put
children.definition: to move sth to a place or position and leave it there:để, đặt vào
examples: put down[M]put sth you are holding onto a surface:để, đặt cái gì đó xuống
▪ She picked up a porcelain figurine and put it down again.
put up[M] fasten something to a wall, ceiling, or in a high position: dán cái gì đó lên
▪ I’m not allowed to put up any posters in my bedroom.

children.name: put something in/on/there etc
examples: ▪ Just put the bags on the table.
▪ I can’t remember where I put my keys.

children.name: put sth backput it in the place where it was before or where it should be:để, đặt cái gì đó lại
examples: ▪ I put the letter back in the envelope.

children.name: put sth awayput it where it is usually kept:để, đặt cái gì đó lại
examples: ▪ It’s time to put everything away now.

children.name: lay
children.definition: to put something on a surface, especially so that it is flat:đặt, để
examples: lay out[M]arrange something carefully on a surface:đặt, để cái gì đó
▪ Before you start packing, lay out all the clothes on the bed.
lay down[M]put sth you are holding onto a surface:đặt, để cái gì đó xuống
▪ Farley laid the gun down and surrendered.

children.name: lay sth on/across sth
examples: ▪ She unfolded the map and laid it on the table.

children.name: place
children.definition: /pleɪs/  to carefully put sth somewhere:đặt

children.name: place sth on/in/over/there etc
examples: ▪ Every week someone comes and places fresh flowers on her grave.
▪ Place some lemon slices on the fish before serving it.
▪ Food is placed in a large cage, and when the animal enters, the door drops down.
▪ Winters placed his hand on my arm, holding me back.

children.name: leave
children.definition: to put sth in a place and not take it with you when you go:để cái gì lại ( cố ý )
examples: ▪ Now, where did I leave my gym shoes?
leave behind[M]B1
We left in a hurry and I must have left my keys behind.

children.name: leave something in/on/on top of etc
examples: Just leave your umbrellas and things behind the door.
She had left all her personal belongings in the London apartment.

children.name: leave sth swh
examples: ▪ I’m sure I left my bag somewhere around here.

children.name: position
children.definition: to carefully move sth into the right position for a particular purpose:đặt vào vị trí
examples: ▪ Make sure you position the wheel correctly before you tighten up the nuts.
▪ Federal troops were positioned around the city.

children.name: deposit
children.definition: to put sth down - used especially when describing events in a formal or humorous way: đặt
examples: Aunt Augusta deposited the contents of her bag on the kitchen table.
After the lessons on the environment, children deposited much more litter in trash cans, rather than dropping it.
The female deposits her eggs directly into the water.

children.name: set
children.definition: 1 putwrittento carefully put something down somewhere
examples: set sth on
Mark filled the pan and set it on the stove.
set sth aside
Remove the mushrooms and set them aside.
set down[M] to put down something big and heavy which you have been carrying - used especially in literature or stories: đặt xuống
The workmen set the box down carefully on the floor.
They set the coffin down in front of the altar.
The movers brought in the dresser, which they set down against the wall.
She set the tray down on a table next to his bed.
2 put into surface[ T always + adv/prep, usually passive ] to put sth into a surface
be set into something
Gates should be hung on sturdy posts set well into the ground.
be set into the wall/floor/ceiling etc(= be built into the surface of something so that it does not stick out )
an alarm button set into the wall beside the door

children.name: abandon
children.definition: to leave sth or go away from a place, vehicle etc permanently, especially because the situation makes it impossible for you to take it with or staySYN leave→abandoned: vứt bỏ
examples: We had to abandon the car and walk the rest of the way.
Fearing further attacks, most of the population had abandoned the city.
Retreating troops were told to abandon their weapons and run as fast as they could towards the beach.
We had to abandon the car.
abandoned[adj] B2an abandoned building, car, boat etc has been left by the people who owned or used it :
The car was found abandoned in Bristol.
the demolition of abandoned buildings

children.name: abandon shipto leave a ship because it is sinking
examples: We were sinking fast, and the captain gave the order to abandonship.

children.name: abandon
children.definition: to leave someone, especially someone you are responsible for:bỏ rơi
examples: How could she abandon her own child?
A new-born baby was found abandoned on the steps of a hospital yesterday.
As a baby he'd been abandoned by his mother.

children.name: leave
children.definition: If you leave something or someone doing something, when you go away they are still doing it
examples: I left the children watchingtelevision.
He left the energy running .

children.name: leave
children.definition: to not take someone with you when you go intentionally
examples: Why don't you leave the kidswithme on Friday?
leavesbbehind[M]B1để ai/ cái gì lại
to leave a place without taking someone or something with you
He was forced to leave the country, leaving behind his wife and children.

children.name: feed
children.partOfSpeech: [ I or T usually + adverb or preposition]
children.definition: verbfed,fedPUT
examples: _[ + two objects ]A member of the princess's staff had been feeding the newspaper information/feeding informationtothe newspaper.
_Several small streams feedinto(= join) the river near here.

children.name: to supply something to a person or thing, orput something into a machine or system,especially in a regular or continuous way
examples: _The vegetables are fedintothe machine at this end.
_The images are fedoversatellite networks to broadcasters throughout the world.

children.name: to put sth in the place where it was before
put back
children.definition: to put something back in the place it is usually kept or in the place it was in before: đặt lại
examples: ▪ Put the cups back in the cupboard when you’ve finished with them.
▪ She took a quick look at the contents of the book, and then put it back on the shelf.
▪ He had tidied up the room and put back all my things where they belonged.

children.name: return
children.definition: /  written to put something back in the place it was before:để lại chỗ cũ
examples: ▪ Johnson carefully returned the document to its hiding place.
▪ Return the pan to the heat and simmer for a further 5-10 minutes.

children.name: plant
children.definition: 1 hide illegal goodsinformalto hide stolen or illegal goods in sb’s clothes, bags, room etc in order to make them seem guilty of a crime : cài
examples: It turned out the security services had planted the documents in his luggage.
He accused the police of planting evidence.

children.name: plant sth on sb
examples: She claims that the police planted the drugs on her.

children.name: 2plant a bomb/explosives etcto put a bomb in a public place: cài bom
examples: Two men are accused of planting a bomb on the plane.

children.name: plant sth in/at/outside/nearby etc
examples: The two men planted the bomb outside Harrods department store in London.

children.name: plant sth in/on/there etc
examples: No rebel group has claimed responsibility for planting the explosives in the van.

children.name: to put paint,make-up etc onto a surface
put on
children.definition: to put sth such a paint or glue onto a surface, or make-up powders and colours that women put on their faces onto your face: son, sơn, thoa
examples: The paint had been put on too thickly, and it had dripped.
When you put the glue on, be careful not to get any on your fingers.
Patricia went upstairs to put on some lipstick.

children.name: apply
children.definition: to put something such as paint or glue onto a surface, or make-up powders and colours that women put on their faces onto your face - used especially in written instructions on how to use it: thoa, sơn
examples: ▪ Apply the cream in the morning and the evening.
▪ Make sure the surface is completely dry before applying the final coat of paint.

children.name: slap on
children.definition: informal to put sth such as paint or glue onto a surface, or make-up powders and colours that women put on their faces onto your face quickly and without much care, and usually in large amounts: trét, thoa,son
examples: Mike was slapping jam on a slice of bread.
Slap on a coat of paint and it will look good as new.
